author: Grimms
text: There were two brothers who were both soldiers; the one was rich and the other poor.

author: Grimms
text: The poor man thought he would try to better himself; so, pulling off his red coat, he became a gardener, and dug his ground well, and sowed turnips.

author: Grimms
text: When the seed came up, there was one plant bigger than all the rest; and it kept getting larger and larger, and seemed as if it would never cease growing; so that it might have been called the prince of turnips for there never was such a one seen before, and never will again.

author: Grimms
text: At last it was so big that it filled a cart, and two oxen could hardly draw it; and the gardener knew not what in the world to do with it, nor whether it would be a blessing or a curse to him.

author: Grimms
text: One day he said to himself, "What shall I do with it? if I sell it, it will bring no more than another; and for eating, the little turnips are better than this; the best thing perhaps is to carry it and give it to the king as a mark of respect."

author: Grimms
text: Then he yoked his oxen, and drew the turnip to the court, and gave it to the king.

author: Grimms
text: "What a wonderful thing!" said the king; "I have seen many strange things, but such a monster as this I never saw.

author: Grimms
text: Where did you get the seed? or is it only your good luck?

author: Grimms
text: If so, you are a true child of fortune."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, no!" answered the gardener, "I am no child of fortune; I am a poor soldier, who never could get enough to live upon; so I laid aside my red coat, and set to work, tilling the ground.

author: Grimms
text: I have a brother, who is rich, and your majesty knows him well, and all the world knows him; but because I am poor, everybody forgets me."

author: Grimms
text: The king then took pity on him, and said, "You shall be poor no longer.

author: Grimms
text: I will give you so much that you shall be even richer than your brother."

author: Grimms
text: Then he gave him gold and lands and flocks, and made him so rich that his brother"s fortune could not at all be compared with his.

author: Grimms
text: When the brother heard of all this, and how a turnip had made the gardener so rich, he envied him sorely, and bethought himself how he could contrive to get the same good fortune for himself.

author: Grimms
text: However, he determined to manage more cleverly than his brother, and got together a rich present of gold and fine horses for the king; and thought he must have a much larger gift in return; for if his brother had received so much for only a turnip, what must his present be wroth?

author: Grimms
text: The king took the gift very graciously, and said he knew not what to give in return more valuable and wonderful than the great turnip; so the soldier was forced to put it into a cart, and drag it home with him.

author: Grimms
text: When he reached home, he knew not upon whom to vent his rage and spite; and at length wicked thoughts came into his head, and he resolved to kill his brother.

author: Grimms
text: So he hired some villains to murder him; and having shown them where to lie in ambush, he went to his brother, and said, "Dear brother, I have found a hidden treasure; let us go and dig it up, and share it between us."

author: Grimms
text: The other had no suspicions of his roguery: so they went out together, and as they were travelling along, the murderers rushed out upon him, bound him, and were going to hang him on a tree.

author: Grimms
text: But whilst they were getting all ready, they heard the trampling of a horse at a distance, which so frightened them that they pushed their prisoner neck and shoulders together into a sack, and swung him up by a cord to the tree, where they left him dangling, and ran away.

author: Grimms
text: Meantime he worked and worked away, till he made a hole large enough to put out his head.

author: Grimms
text: When the horseman came up, he proved to be a student, a merry fellow, who was journeying along on his nag, and singing as he went.

author: Grimms
text: As soon as the man in the sack saw him passing under the tree, he cried out, "Good morning! good morning to thee, my friend!"

author: Grimms
text: The student looked about everywhere; and seeing no one, and not knowing where the voice came from, cried out, "Who calls me?"

author: Grimms
text: Then the man in the tree answered, "Lift up thine eyes, for behold here I sit in the sack of wisdom; here have I, in a short time, learned great and wondrous things.

author: Grimms
text: Compared to this seat, all the learning of the schools is as empty air.

author: Grimms
text: A little longer, and I shall know all that man can know, and shall come forth wiser than the wisest of mankind.

author: Grimms
text: Here I discern the signs and motions of the heavens and the stars; the laws that control the winds; the number of the sands on the seashore; the healing of the sick; the virtues of all simples, of birds, and of precious stones.

author: Grimms
text: Wert thou but once here, my friend, though wouldst feel and own the power of knowledge.

author: Grimms
text: The student listened to all this and wondered much; at last he said, "Blessed be the day and hour when I found you; cannot you contrive to let me into the sack for a little while?"

author: Grimms
text: Then the other answered, as if very unwillingly, "A little space I may allow thee to sit here, if thou wilt reward me well and entreat me kindly; but thou must tarry yet an hour below, till I have learnt some little matters that are yet unknown to me."

author: Grimms
text: So the student sat himself down and waited a while; but the time hung heavy upon him, and he begged earnestly that he might ascend forthwith, for his thirst for knowledge was great.

author: Grimms
text: Then the other pretended to give way, and said, "Thou must let the sack of wisdom descend, by untying yonder cord, and then thou shalt enter."

author: Grimms
text: So the student let him down, opened the sack, and set him free.

author: Grimms
text: "Now then," cried he, "let me ascend quickly."

author: Grimms
text: As he began to put himself into the sack heels first, "Wait a while," said the gardener, "that is not the way."

author: Grimms
text: Then he pushed him in head first, tied up the sack, and soon swung up the searcher after wisdom dangling in the air.

author: Grimms
text: "How is it with thee, friend?" said he, "dost thou not feel that wisdom comes unto thee?

author: Grimms
text: Rest there in peace, till thou art a wiser man than thou wert."

author: Grimms
text: So saying, he trotted off on the student"s nag, and left the poor fellow to gather wisdom till somebody should come and let him down.
